title: 110_hr719
content:
The Act titled "Keeping the Internet Devoid of Sexual Predators Act of 2007" or "KIDS Act of 2007" authorizes additional appropriations for the supervision of internet access by sex offenders convicted under federal law. Authorized appropriations of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2013 for evaluating, purchasing, and training probation officers in internet filtering and monitoring programs, as well as supervision of sex offenders. To effectively supervise convicted sex offenders, probation officers and other personnel may be hired as needed. SEC. 3. Discretionary condition of probation and supervised release for sex offenders. Probation conditions for sex offenders under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act include accessing the Internet only from approved computers, consenting to computer examinations by the probation officer, and allowing for the removal of computer equipment for thorough inspections. The probation conditions for sex offenders include consenting to computer monitoring and restrictions on web access designated by the probation officer. The defendant must also allow for computer inspections and monitoring systems to ensure compliance with the law and protect public safety. They are prohibited from disabling or evading these measures. The probation conditions for sex offenders include computer monitoring and restrictions on web access. Offenders must allow for inspections and monitoring to ensure compliance with the law and public safety. They are not allowed to disable or evade these measures. Amendments are made to supervised release conditions in the United States Code. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for sex offenders involving children using the Internet. Modifications will be made to electronic monitoring standards for sexual offender monitoring programs. The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 is amended to include minimum standards for electronic monitoring units in a pilot program for offenders. The tracking device must have a central processing unit with a global positioning system and allow continuous monitoring 24 hours a day. This amendment applies to grants provided after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 6. FINANCIAL FACILITATION OF ACCESS TO CHILD PORNOGRAPHY. Amends Chapter 95 of title 18, United States Code to include a new section (Sec. 1960A) that penalizes conducting financial transactions to facilitate access to child pornography with fines or imprisonment up to 20 years. Adds a new item to the table of sections. 

SEC. 7. CHANGE IN DEFINITION OF MONETARY INSTRUMENTS FOR MONEY LAUNDERING AND OTHER OFFENSES. Section 1956(c)(5) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include electronic currencies, digital currencies, and stored value cards. Passed by the House of Representatives on November 14, 2007.
